Heading: NASA’s Juno probe completes first Jupiter flyby

Heading: Virtual peer pressure can spark competition, boost performance

NASA is set to launch its first mission to return pristine samples of an asteroid to Earth, which will help study how planets formed and how life began.
The findings may also improve our understanding of asteroids that could impact Earth, researchers said.

Heading: ‘Mars rover Curiosity can now fire laser on its own’
Summary: “The science team is not always available to pick samples for analysis. Having a smarter rover that can pick its own samples is completely in line with self-driving cars and other smart technologies being implemented on Earth,” said Wiens

Heading: How humans made ropes 40,000 years ago

Heading: China aims for manned moon landing by 2036

Heading: Hubble spots galaxy hiding in the night sky
Summary: The Hubble Space Telescope has spotted a galaxy hidden in the night sky, located just over 110 million light-years away in the constellation of Pisces(The Fish).

Heading: Collider and the weasel: Pop went the weasel and down went the Large Hadron Collider
Summary: Large Hadron Collider. It’s one of the physics world’s most complex machines, and it has been immobilized – temporarily – by a weasel.

Heading: Bacteria may provide clues to how birds got wings
Summary: Scientists have used bacteria to show that gene duplication allows organisms to evolve new attributes such as wings, horns or limbs.

Heading: ‘Walnuts may help in inhibiting colon cancer risk factors’
Summary: Lipid extract from walnuts may positively affect the self-renewal capacity of cancer stem cells (CSCs) in colon cancer, the second leading cause of cancer deaths worldwide, new research has found.

Heading: NASA-inspired ‘miracle suit’ saving new mothers from death, including in India
Summary: Inspired by NASA research on inflated anti-gravity suit or G-suit, “miracle suits” are helping new mothers survive blood loss after birth in developing countries, including in India.

Heading: ISRO successfully launches IRNSS-1G satellite from Sriharikota; India gets its own GPS
Summary: ISRO’s IRNSS-1G: The flawless launch from Sriharikota, the seventh satellite in the navigation system, marks a big milestone for India as it gets its own GPS.

Heading: Microscopic ‘timers’ reveal likely source of cosmic rays: NASA
Summary: Microscopic “timers” have revealed the likely source of galactic radiation that we detect at Earth. Most of the cosmic rays originated relatively recently in the nearby clusters of massive stars, according to new results from NASA’s Advanced Composition Explorer (ACE) spacecraft.

Heading: Ashes from ‘nearby’ supernova explosion 2.3 mn years ago, still raining on Earth
Summary: It’s still raining ashes on Earth. A team of scientists has found that majority of cosmic rays raining on earth today were sent by a nearby supernova about 2.3 million years ago.

Heading: IRNSS-1G launch: PM Narendra Modi, President Pranab Mukherjee & other leaders congratulate ISRO for India’s own GPS
Summary: “Congratulations to ISRO team on successful launch of PSLV-C33 carrying IRNSS-1G,” the President wrote on micro-blogging site Twitter.

Heading: ISRO: 51.30 hour PSLV-XL countdown starts for launch of India’s IRNSS-1G navigation satellite
Summary: “The countdown started at 9.20 a.m. The rocket PSLV-XL (polar satellite launch vehicle) will blast off from the first launch pad at 12.50 p.m. on April 28,” P.Kunhikrishnan, director, Satish Dhawan Space Centre (SDSC), Sriharikota said over phone.

Heading: Flight test of RLV-TD next month end: ISRO Chief A S Kiran Kumar
Summary: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) will flight test RLV-TD, a new generation reusable launch vehicle that can re-enter the atmosphere, next month end, the agency Chairman A S Kiran Kumar said today.

Heading: Is planet Earth in ‘quake mode’? Concerned experts watch closely
Summary: Certain “high risk zones” around the world do require a close watch, geophysicists now believe after a spate of high-intensity earthquakes rattled different parts of the world and reignited the question whether the Earth is experiencing another round of seismic-active period.

Heading: Lab-grown ‘mini brains’ reveal how Zika virus takes its toll
Summary: A team of researchers has discovered how the Zika virus stunts head and brain development, thanks to ‘mini-brains’.

Heading: ISRO’s IRNSS-1G: PM Narendra Modi terms India’s own GPS ‘Navic’; calls it an example of ‘Make in India’
Summary: PM Modi termed ISRO’s IRNSS as ‘Navic’, inviting SAARC nations to “navigate with Indian constellation” of satellites.

Heading: Dinosaurs struggled to survive long before asteroid hit
Summary: Dinosaurs struggled to survive for tens of millions of years before they finally went extinct, an event widely blamed on the environmental fallout from an asteroid strike, researchers have said.

Heading: Monkey mariners made monumental migration 21 million years ago
Summary: Monkeys resembling today’s capuchins accomplished the astonishing feat of crossing at least 100 miles (160 km) of open ocean 21 million years ago to get from South America to North America eons before the two continents joined together.

Heading: Blocking a molecule may help better treat asthma
Summary: Scientists, including one of Indian-origin, have found that blocking a certain signalling molecule may alleviate the symptoms of asthma, a discovery that could lead to improved treatment for sufferers.

Heading: NASA turns to students to design 3D printed expandable objects
Summary: To celebrate the arrival of the first expandable habitat to the ISS and the launch of the first commercial 3D printer to space, the ASME Foundation and NASA have issued a brand new Future Engineers challenge.

Heading: Dinosaur die-off not a result of volcanoes in India: Study
Summary: Volcanic eruptions in what is now India did not lead to the extinction of the dinosaurs about 65 million years ago, a new study suggests.

Heading: NASA set to build an array of new X-planes
Summary: NASA scientists are preparing to put in the sky an array of new X-planes or experimental aircraft – including a quiet supersonic jet – to demonstrate advanced technologies that will push back the frontiers of aviation.

Heading: ISRO’s rocket technology to power human hearts
Summary: Rocket science may not be able to fix broken hearts, but very soon technology mastered at the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) may be able to help patients who are in need for a heart transplant.

Heading: Chinese scientists successfully develop embryos in space
Summary: Chinese scientists said that they have successfully developed early-stage mouse embryos in space for the first time on a retrievable microgravity satellite set to return to Earth next week.

Heading: US space industry opposes use of ISRO launch vehicles; says tough to compete
Summary: Corporate leaders and officials of the fast-emerging American private space industry said it would be tough for them to compete against low-cost ISRO launch vehicles.

Heading: Sunita Williams trains with gen-next spaceflight simulators
Summary: Indian-American Sunita Williams and other NASA commercial crew astronauts have tested a new generation of training simulators to prepare for launch, flight and returns aboard a Boeing spacecraft that will transport crew to the International Space Station (ISS).

Heading: Countdown for ISRO’s navigation satellite IRNSS-IG begins in Sriharikota
Summary: The 51:30 hour countdown for the April 28 launch of the country’s seventh and final navigation satellite, IRNSS-1G, on board Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle- C33 from the spaceport of Sriharikota, about 110 km from here, began today.

Heading: ‘Param Kanchenjunga’ fastest supercomputer among NITs
Summary: The National Institute of Technology (NIT) Sikkim has recently established a supercomputer ‘Param Kanchenjunga’, which is said to be fastest among all 31 NITs, an official said.

Heading: NASA: Hubble Space Telescope spots super-hot star ‘inflating’ giant bubble, 7,100 light-years from Earth
Summary: To mark the 26th anniversary of the launch of NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope, astronomers have unveiled an image captured by it of an enormous bubble being blown into space by a super-hot, massive star located 7,100 light-years from Earth.

Heading: Make your own auto fuel with used cooking oil
Summary: Do not throw away leftover cooking oil. You can convert it into biodiesel in a microwave and use that to run your car. Turning cooking oil into auto fuel in an economical way is now possible with a new processing technique demonstrated by a team of scientists from Israel’s Bar-Ilan University.

Heading: Wives become less stressed after husband’s death: Study
Summary: Marriage has long been thought to be beneficial, but a new study suggests that widows suffer less stress and frailty than women whose husbands are still alive.

Heading: Isro’s IRNSS-1G navigation satellite launched from Sriharikota: Top 7 things to know about India’s own GPS
Summary: Isro’s IRNSS-1G navigation satellite launched on Thursday from the spaceport of Sriharikota in Andhra Pradesh carrying India’s seventh and last navigation satellite.

Heading: Dark matter isn’t made of certain axion-like particles
Summary: A team of researchers has ruled some axion-like particles out as the dark matter’s content. Physicists are still struggling with the conundrum of identifying more than 80 percent of the matter in the Universe.

Heading: IRNSS: India closer to its own GPS; ISRO’s IRNSS-1G satellite to launch on April 28
Summary: The Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System comprising seven satellites would be able to provide navigation system with much better accuracy and targeted position.

Heading: Barack Obama praises young Indian-American science wizards
Summary: Maya Varma from California and Anarudh Ganesan from Maryland won various science competitions, thus qualifying for the sixth White House Science Fair.

Heading: New ‘self-powered’ smart skin helps robots get ‘touchy’
Summary: Smart skin technology helps robots sense the world, but keeping them powered up and highly sensitive at low cost has been a challenge. Now, a team of scientists has come up with a self-powered, transparent smart skin that is simpler and less costly than others.

Heading: NASA’s planet-hunting Kepler spacecraft enters emergency mode
Summary: NASA’s Kepler spacecraft, that hunts for Earth-like planets orbiting other stars, has gone into emergency mode some 75 million miles from Earth, the US space agency said.

Heading: Electrical brain stimulation enhances creativity: Study
Summary: Researchers from the Georgetown University Medical Centre (GUMC) in US used Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) to stimulate an area of the brain known to be associated with creativity in combination with giving test subjects verbal cues to think more creatively.

Heading: Jupiter’s moon creates enough heat to support ocean: Study
Summary: Jupiter exerts a strong gravitational pull on Europa, creating far more heat on the moon’s ice-sheet than earlier thought, which may be enough to support a sub-surface ocean, a new study suggests.

Heading: Sunshine’s droppings could shed light on panda diet mystery
Summary: Britain’s only giant pandas, Tian Tian and Yang Guang, are taking part in an experiment to find out whether the famously faddy breed really does only eat shoots and leaves.

Heading: This new roundworm species from India is ‘unique’
Summary: The unique features and blending characters have made a new roundworm species from India a distinct yet intermediary or connecting link between two supposedly distant genera, according to a study.

Heading: Sexually transmitted diseases, peer pressure drove ancient humans to marriage, monogamy
Summary: According to a study, the root of marriage can be traced back to nothing romantic, rather it may have been started just to avoid sexually transmitted diseases (STIs).

Heading: Ancient asteroids enhanced life supporting habitat on Mars
Summary: Large comets and asteroids that bombarded Mars some 4 billion years ago likely enhanced climate conditions enough to make the red planet more conducive to life, at least for a time, a new study has found.

Heading: Ocean salt level may affect climate on Earth-like planets
Summary: Salt levels of oceans on distant Earth-like planets affect their climates, according to a new study which found that extremely salty or fresh water seas may make a planet more habitable for alien life.

Heading: North-pole had ice-free summers 6 to 10 million years ago: Study
Summary: The central Arctic was completely ice-free during summers some six to 10 million years ago and the sea-surface temperature reached four to nine degrees Celsius, a new study has found.

Heading: Human-like robots to soon treat social disorders
Summary: A team from European universities created a system to enable a robot or computer avatar to interact with a patient while playing a version of the mirror game, in which two players try to copy each other’s motion while playing with coloured balls that can move horizontally on a string.

Heading: Chip paves way for deeper understanding of black holes
Summary: A breakthrough chip for the nano-manipulation of light has pioneered new paths for developing next generation optical technologies and enabling deeper understanding of black holes.

Heading: NASA pioneering programme: Indian-origin scientist Ratnakumar Bugga selected
Summary: An Indian-origin scientist’s proposal has been selected for NASA’s Innovative Advanced Concepts (NIAC) programme — an initiative that invests in transformative architectures through the development of pioneering technologies.

Heading: Saturn probe detects interstellar dust
Summary: Cassini has been in orbit around Saturn since 2004, studying the giant planet, its rings and its moons. The spacecraft has also sampled millions of ice-rich dust grains with its cosmic dust analyser instrument.

Heading: NASA selects Indian-origin researcher for innovative concept
Summary: NASA has selected 13 proposals, including one by an Indian-origin scientist, through the NASA Innovative Advanced Concepts (NIAC), a programme aimed at revolutionising future space missions to Mars and beyond.

Heading: SpaceX’s Dragon cargo ship arrives at ISS with inflatable space habitat
Summary: SpaceX’s Dragon cargo ship arrived at the International Space Station (ISS) on Sunday, carrying an experimental inflatable space habitat that might be crucial for future deep space explorations.

Heading: Billionaire Yuri Milner bids another $100 mn to explore the cosmos
Summary: Billionaire Internet investor Yuri Milner announced another $100 million initiative on Tuesday to better understand the cosmos, this time by deploying thousands of tiny spacecraft to travel to our nearest neighboring star system and send back pictures.

Heading: Heat stress to ‘cripple’ densely populated regions by mid-century
Summary: Extreme heat can be fatal and now, a team of researchers has projected crippling heat stress in densely populated regions by mid-century.

Heading: Like humans, Neanderthals used toothpicks too: study
Summary: Scientists have found evidence that Neanderthals, the extinct cousins of modern humans, may have used toothpicks to remove food out of their teeth, just like us.

Heading: New mathematical models predict where to find fossils
Summary: Scientists have built a series of mathematical models to determine the areas in Australia most likely to contain fossils of long-extinct animals.

Heading: Giant black hole found in an unlikely place
Summary: The near-record breaking black hole, weighing 17 billion suns, was discovered in the centre of a galaxy, in a sparsely populated area of the universe.

Heading: Supernova iron discovered on Earth’s Moon
Summary: This supernova hypothesis was first put forth in 1999 by researchers at the TUM who had found initial evidence in a deep-sea crust.

Heading: SpaceX launches inflatable space habitat to ISS
Summary: US space firm SpaceX resumed its resupply mission to the International Space Station (ISS) on Friday, carrying aboard an experimental inflatable space habitat that might be crucial for future deep space explorations.

Heading: Fossil fuels could be phased out globally in just 10 yrs
Summary: Burning of fossil fuels is very concerning, but now a team of researchers has suggested that the worldwide reliance on burning fossil fuels could be phased out in just 10 years.

Heading: Scientists: Greenland ice sheet is melting freakishly early
Summary: Greenland’s massive ice sheet this week started melting freakishly early because of a weather system that brought unseasonably warm temperatures and rain, scientists say.

Heading: Intelsat signs up for Orbital’s satellite life-extension service
Summary: Intelsat SA will be the first customer for Orbital ATK Inc’s new service that will use robotic vehicles to fix damaged satellites in space, the companies said on Tuesday.

Heading: Virtual Earth-space telescope reveals new details of Milky Way galaxy; temp hotter than 10 tn degrees
Summary: Astronomers have created a virtual Earth-space radio telescope more than 100,000 miles across – a super-high resolution that reveals new details of a quasar and our Milky Way. The researchers were surprised when their Earth-space system revealed a temperature hotter then 10 trillion degrees.

Heading: Impulsive people may be prone to substance abuse: Study
Summary: People who are prone to seeking excitement and acting impulsively may have differences in the structure of their brains, which may also predispose them to substance abuse, a new study has found.

Heading: Solar storms trigger Jupiter’s ‘Northern Lights’
Summary: Solar storms trigger Jupiter’s intense ‘Northern Lights’ by generating a new X-ray aurora that is eight times brighter than normal and hundreds of times more energetic than Earth’s aurora borealis, a new study has found, using data from NASA’s Chandra X-Ray Observatory.

Heading: Human impact affects Earth’s global energy flow
Summary: The impact that human beings have made on the Earth in terms of production and consumption of natural resources has formed a ‘striking new pattern’ in the planet’s global energy flow, finds a new research.

Heading: Sun may produce devastating ‘superflares’: Study
Summary: The Sun is capable of producing monstrous eruptions or ‘superflares’ that can not only break down radio communication and power supplies, but also affect Earth’s ability to support life, scientists say. Earth is often struck by solar eruptions. These eruptions consist of energetic particles that are hurled away from the Sun into space, where those directed towards Earth encounter the magnetic field around our planet.

Heading: Human impact affects Earth’s global energy flow: Study
Summary: The impact humans have made on Earth in terms of how they produce and consume resources has formed a ‘striking new pattern’ in the planet’s global energy flow, according to a new study.

Heading: NASA, Microsoft team up to bring you closer to Mars
Summary: The US space agency and tech giant Microsoft have teamed up to create “Destination: Mars”, a guided tour of Mars using the same Hololens headset technology that helps scientists plan the Curiosity rover’s activities on Red Planet.

Heading: NASA to undertake globe-spanning research campaigns
Summary: NASA is sending scientists around the world this year – from the edge of the Greenland ice sheet to the coral reefs of the South Pacific…

Heading: Fungi to be sent to space station by SpaceX
Summary: Fungi will be sent for the first time to the International Space Station for the development of medicine, said researchers at the University of Southern California (USC).

Heading: Ocean salt level may affect climate on Earth-like planets
Summary:
However, studying their oceans is vital for understanding climate stability and habitability – as on our own Earth.
Until now, researchers had not considered that the seas on Earth-like planets might not be quite like ours – they might be significantly more or less salty than the oceans on Earth.

Heading: Moon plays key role in maintaining Earth’s magnetic field
Summary: The Moon may play a major role in maintaining Earth’s magnetic field that permanently protects us from the charged particles and radiation that originate in the Sun, according to a new study.

Heading: Goal to reduce world temperatures likely to fail: Study
Summary: The goals to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in order to limit global warming to less than two degrees Celsius set in December last year in Paris are almost impossible to achieve, according to a new study. In December last year, officials representing more than 190 countries met in Paris to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference.

Heading: NASA Spitzer Space Telescope temperature map of ‘Super Earth’ reveals lava world
Summary: Using data from NASA’s Spitzer Space Telescope, an international team of astronomers that also includes an Indian-origin scientist has for the first time obtained the most detailed “fingerprint” of a super-Earth planet – a rocky planet nearly two times as big as ours.

Heading: High-protein diet to blame for Neanderthals’ extinction?
Summary: The total dependence of Neanderthals on large animals to satisfy their fat and protein needs may provide a clue to their eventual extinction, say researchers. Homo sapiens, the ancestor of modern humans, shared the planet with Neanderthals, a close, heavy-set relative that dwelled almost exclusively in Ice-Age Europe, until some 40,000 years ago.

Heading: NASA’s Cassini mission reveals tallest peaks at Saturn’s moon Titan
Summary: In a nod to extraterrestrial mountaineers of the future, scientists working on NASA’s Cassini mission have identified the highest point on Saturn’s largest moon Titan. Titan’s tallest peak is 10,948 feet high and is found within a trio of mountainous ridges called the Mithrim Montes.

Heading: New planet with triple-star system found
Summary: Scientists have discovered a rare triple-star system with a gas giant planet similar in size to Jupiter.

Heading: Road rage, aggression linked to common brain parasite
Summary: In the study involving 358 adult subjects, researchers from the University of Chicago found that toxoplasmosis, a relatively harmless parasitic infection carried by about 30 per cent of all humans, was linked to intermittent explosive disorder (IED) and increased aggression.

Heading: Artificial functional skin may help burn victims
Summary: Scientists have successfully grown complex 3D skin tissue from stem cells in the lab, complete with hair follicles and oil-secreting glands…

Heading: NASA clears another hurdle for its mega spacecraft to Mars
Summary: The US space agency, which is working on the “spacecraft of the future” for journey to Mars, has completed a successful review of facilities and ground support systems for the mega Space Launch System (SLS) rocket and Orion spacecraft at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

Heading: Mile-high Mars mounds built by wind: Study
Summary: The massive mounds of more than a mile high on Mars were carved by wind over billions of years, according to a new study that may help pin down when water on the red planet dried up during a climate change event.

Heading: NASA lines up globe-spanning research on Earth
Summary: NASA is sending scientists around the world this year – from the edge of the Greenland ice sheet to the coral reefs of the South Pacific…

Heading: Quantum computing: Key challenge overcome, say researchers
Summary: A group of researchers has recently overcome one of the key challenges to quantum computing by simplifying a complex quantum logic operation. Researchers from Griffith University and the University of Queensland demonstrated this by experimentally realising a challenging circuit the quantum Fredkin gate for the first time.

Heading: Our moon tilted by five degrees, lunar ice reveals
Summary: New NASA-funded research provides evidence that the spin axis of Earth’s moon shifted by about five degrees roughly three billion years ago.

Heading: ‘Siberian unicorn’ may have roamed Earth longer than thought
Summary: The “Siberian unicorn” – an ancient rhinoceros species thought to have gone extinct 350,000 years ago – may have found its last refuge as recently as 29,000 years ago in Kazakhstan, scientists say.

Heading: Hubble unveils half a million stars at Milky Way’s heart
Summary: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope has unveiled a rich tapestry of more than half a million tightly packed stars at the heart of our Milky Way galaxy.

Heading: Move over glass, here comes transparent wood
Summary: A team of researchers has managed to transform real wood into still-real transparent wood, paving way for greener homes.

Heading: Four Indian teams to compete in NASA ‘Human Exploration Rover Challenge’
Summary: Four groups of Indian students are part of nearly 80 teams that will participate in the US space agency’s “Human Exploration Rover Challenge” to help NASA realise its goals for future exploration to Mars and beyond.

Heading: NASA cargo mission with key science supplies on way to ISS
Summary: Carrying 7,500 pounds (3,400 kg) of key science research, the Orbital ATK Cygnus spacecraft is currently on it way to the International Space Station (ISS).

Heading: Baby monkeys grow faster to avoid infanticide
Summary: Some baby monkeys develop faster than others in the same population, and this is best explained by the threat of infanticide they face from adult males, says a study. “Infanticide occurs in many animals, including carnivores like lions and bears, rodents like mice, and in primates,” said lead researcher Iulia Badescu from University of Toronto. […]

Heading: New model to decode what invisible dark matter is
Summary: Researchers have presented a new model for what dark matter might be, a discovery that can lead scientists to invisible dark matter that is all around us yet no one has ever seen it and no one knows what it really is. Physical calculations state that approximately 27 percent of the universe is dark matter. […]

Heading: New Horizons collects only a few dust grains during Pluto flyby
Summary: Data downloaded and analysed by the New Horizons team indicated the space environment around Pluto and its moons contained only about six dust particles per cubic mile, Fran Bagenal, who leads the New Horizons Particles and Plasma Team.

Heading: Exploding star’s shockwave captured for the first time by NASA planet-hunter, the Kepler space telescope
Summary: Analysing data from NASA’s planet-hunter, the Kepler space telescope, astronomers have captured for the first time a brilliant flash of an exploding star’s shockwave or “shock breakout” in optical wavelength or visible light.

Heading: Pregnant T Rex sheds light on sex-linked traits in extinct dinosaurs
Summary: Paleontologists have found the presence of a gender-specific reproductive tissue in a Tyrannosaurus Rex (T.Rex) that roamed Montana in the US 68 million years ago, thereby allowing them to determine the gender of this fossil.

Heading: Climate change: Trees adapt to higher temperatures, limiting global warming impact
Summary: Climate change: Trees can adapt to rising temperatures and limit their natural emissions of greenhouse gases, according to a study published on Wednesday that suggests plants may have a smaller than expected role in stoking man-made global warming.

Heading: Scans show hidden chambers behind Tutankhamen’s tomb
Summary: Scans of King Tutankhamen’s tomb have almost certainly shown two rooms hidden behind the pharaoh’s burial chamber, Egyptian Antiquities Minister Mamdouh al-Damati said on Thursday.

Heading: Protective magnetic field helped life begin on Earth
Summary: Not just water and oxygen, life thrived on early Earth thanks to another necessary ingredient: the presence of a protective magnetic field.

Heading: Bermuda Triangle mystery almost solved?
Summary: Scientists now believe that they have come a step closer to one of the greatest mysteries of the world, Bermuda Triangle, which gulps aircraft and ships.

Heading: Blondes are actually not ‘dumb’: Study
Summary: The stereotype that “blondes are dumb” is simply wrong, according to a new US study which found that the average IQ of light-haired people may actually be slightly higher than those with other hair colours.

Heading: Soon, clothes that can clean themselves with light
Summary: A spot of sunshine is all it could take to clean your clothes within minutes, as scientists, including those of Indian-origin, have developed a low-cost, efficient way to grow nanostructures on textiles that can degrade organic matter when exposed to light.

Heading: Earth set for hotter, drier, wetter future: Researcher (March 23 is World Meteorological Day)
Summary: There is strong evidence that the Earth is already one degree Celsius hotter than at the start of the 20th century – and the past four years have been the hottest on record. All this is a a foretaste of a hotter, drier and wetter future, says an international researcher.

Heading: Most ‘outrageously luminous’ galaxies ever discovered
Summary: Astronomers have observed the most luminous galaxies ever seen in the universe – objects so bright that the researchers have taken to calling them ‘outrageously luminous’.

Heading: New golden frog species found
Summary: Its name, Pristimantis dorado, commemorates both its colour (dorado means ‘golden’ in Spanish) and El Dorado, a mythical city of gold eagerly sought for centuries by Spanish conquistadores in South America.

Heading: New ExoMars mission to find alien life on way to Red Planet
Summary: A new era of Mars exploration for Europe began on Monday as a new mission jointly developed by the European Space Agency (ESA) and the Russian Federal Space Agency (Roscosmos) blasted into the sky on a Russian Proton rocket to find if Red Planet has traces of alien life.

Heading: New NASA probe to boost sonic boom investigation
Summary: A new air data probe by NASA may improve the investigation to control and lessen the noise of sonic booms so that the US federal regulators allow commercial supersonic flights soon.

Heading: How our brain traces old memories?
Summary: A team of German scientists has found out what actually happens if we try to remember things that took place years or decades ago? The study revealed that the neural networks involved in retrieving very old memories are quite distinct from those used to remember recent events.

Heading: NASA: Hubble Space Telescope unveils nine new monster stars
Summary: Using the unique ultraviolet capabilities of the NASA Hubble Space Telescope, an international team of scientists has identified nine monster stars with masses over 100 times the mass of the sun in the star cluster R136.

Heading: New human stem cells hold hope for humanity
Summary: A team of scientists has succeeded in generating new type of embryonic stem cells that carry a single copy of the human genome instead of the two copies typically found in normal stem cells.

Heading: ‘Outrageously luminous’ galaxies ever discovered
Summary: Astronomers have observed the most luminous galaxies ever seen in the universe — objects so bright that descriptors such as “ultra” and “hyper-luminous” don’t even come close.

Heading: NASA scientists reveal Pluto and its moons
Summary: NASA scientists associated with interplanetary space probe New Horizons have revealed the former “astronomer’s planet” and its “intriguing system of small moons” in a comprehensive set of papers describing results from last summer’s Pluto system flyby.

Heading: Human DNA to help create faster, cheaper chips soon
Summary: DNA, the genetic material of life, may help engineers build faster, cheaper computer chips by forming specific shapes through a process reminiscent of the ancient art of paper folding, researchers report.

Heading: Astronaut Scott Kelly to retire from NASA in April
Summary: Astronaut Scott Kelly will retire from NASA next month, after spending nearly a year in space and setting a record for the most cumulative days in space of any American, the US space agency said.

Heading: What is a Tully Monster? Scientists finally provide an answer
Summary: For more than half a century, scientists have scratched their heads over the nature of an outlandishly bizarre creature dubbed the Tully Monster that flourished about 307 million years ago in a coastal estuary in what is now northeastern Illinois.

Heading: Scientists develop new human stem cells with half a genome
Summary: Scientists for the first time have generated a type of embryonic stem cell that carries a single copy of the human genome rather than the usual two, a development that could advance research in gene editing, genetic screening and regenerative medicine.

Heading: For an experiment, NASA to set ‘large scale fire’ in space
Summary: NASA’s John H Glenn Research Centre is going to light a “large scale fire” in space as part of an experiment that seeks to understand how fire spreads in a micro-gravity environment.

Heading: Countdown for Indian rocket launch progressing smoothly
Summary: The 54-hour 30 minutes countdown for the launch of an Indian rocket carrying the country’s sixth navigation satellite as the sole passenger is progressing smoothly, said a senior official of the Indian space agency.

Heading: Solar eclipse in India on Wednesday
Summary: India will witness a solar eclipse on Wednesday morning, the first in 2016 but it will only be briefly visible in Delhi, said the IMD.

Heading: Albert Einstein equations: New study shows formation of structures in universe
Summary: A new code of numerical simulations have been developed which offers a glimpse of the complex process of the formation of structures in the universe. Based on Albert Einstein’s equations, the physicists at the University of Geneva were able to integrate the rotation of space-time

Heading: New species of reptile identified from 250-million-year-old fossil
Summary: Scientists have discovered a new fossil reptile that lived 250 million years ago in Brazil, which may help understand the origins of dinosaurs, flying reptiles and crocodiles.

Heading: Climate change wiped out prehistoric ‘sea dragon’ on Earth: Study
Summary: Prehistoric global warming wiped out the ichthyosaur, a toothy, dolphin-like reptile that disappeared from Earth’s oceans tens of millions of years before the last dinosaurs, researchers said today.

Heading: PSLV C-32 launch time delayed by 1 min to avoid space debris
Summary: The lift-off of India’s polar rocket carrying its navigational satellite IRNSS-1F from here was today delayed by one minute just before the launch to avoid any possibility of collision with space debris.

Heading: Citizen sky gazers helping NASA unlock sizzling auroras
Summary: The US space agency is using citizen science observations to unlock the secrets behind auroras — geomagnetic storms that are beautiful but can also cause power outages and interrupt satellite systems. One such space weather scientist, Liz MacDonald has seen auroras more than five times in her life.

Heading: New study shows formation of structures in universe
Summary: A new code of numerical simulations have been developed which offers a glimpse of the complex process of the formation of structures in the universe. Based on Albert Einstein’s equations, the physicists at the University of …

Heading: Cancer cells get their fuel from neighbours’ ‘words’
Summary: A recent study has revealed that cancer cells get 30-60 percent of their fuel from eating their neighbours’ ‘words’.

Heading: Gene behind evolution of intelligent life identified
Summary: Scientists have identified a common ancestral gene that enabled the evolution of advanced life more than a billion years ago, and without which life on our planet would probably still be bacterial slime. The gene, found in all complex organisms, including plants and animals, encodes for a large group of enzymes known as protein kinases that enabled cells to be larger and to rapidly transfer information from one part to another.

Heading: Stephen Hawking urges Britain to remain in EU
Summary: Renowned cosmologist Stephen Hawking was among 150 academics to declare support for Britain remaining in the European Union today in a letter that said leaving the bloc would damage science and research.

Heading: ISRO to launch 1,425-kg IRNSS-1F navigation satellite aboard PSLV rocket on Thursday
Summary: India is slated to put into orbit its sixth navigation satelliteon Thursday evening, the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) announced here on Monday.

Heading: Iceberg that sank Titanic was 100,000 years old: Experts
Summary: The giant iceberg responsible for sinking the Titanic on its maiden voyage may have originated in southwest Greenland in snow that fell about 100,000 years ago, scientists say.

Heading: ‘Star Trek’: Science fiction turns science fact
Summary: Automatic doors, video telephony or flip phones and teleporting – these revolutionary ideas were presented in the movie ‘Star Trek.’

Heading: ISRO to test plane-shaped reusable rocket
Summary: India will test a small aeroplane-shaped vehicle this year as part of its programme to develop a reusable space launch vehicle, a senior official of Indian Space Research Organisation said. “We will test a small aeroplane-shaped vehicle – reusable launch vehicle technology demonstrator – weighing around 1.7 tonnes soon.

Heading: Asteroid 2013 TX68 may impact Earth in 2017: NASA
Summary: NASA has dramatically changed its mind about the risks posed by asteroid 2013 TX68 , a 100ft-wide rock which is currently heading towards Earth. NASA’s initial estimate showed the whale-sized space rock may skim past Earth at just 11,000 miles (17,000 km), which is around 21 times closer to Earth than the moon…

Heading: ISRO set to launch India’s sixth navigation satellite IRNSS-1F on PSLV rocket at 4 p.m. on Thursday
Summary: The 54 hour, 30 minute countdown status for the March 10 launch of an Indian rocket with the country’s sixth navigation satellite is proceeding normally, the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) said on Wednesday.

Heading: Evolution of fins to limbs in Tetrapods was simple
Summary: Limbs of the earliest four-legged vertebrates, dating back more than 360 million years, were no more structurally diverse than the fins of their aquatic ancestors, reveals a new study.

Heading: What is the mystery behind Mercury ‘darkness’?
Summary: Though it is nearest to the sun, Mercury’s surface is immensely dark. So, what is the ‘darkening agent’? About a year ago, scientists proposed that Mercury’s darkness was due to carbon that gradually accumulated from the impact of comets that travelled into the inner Solar System.

Heading: New model shows how infections cross from mom to baby
Summary: Scientists have devised a cell-based model of the human placenta that could help explain how pathogens that cause birth defects, such as Zika virus, cross from a mother to her unborn child.

Heading: Rare ‘Curious Marie’ that helped form solar system discovered
Summary: The team found evidence of curium in an unusual ceramic inclusion they called “Curious Marie”, taken from a carbonaceous meteorite.

Heading: NASA asteroid hunting spacecraft in key testing phase
Summary: The first US mission to collect a sample of an asteroid and return it to Earth in September this year is undergoing a major milestone in its environmental testing.

Heading: Scientists develop mind-controlled wheelchair
Summary: “In some severely disabled people, even blinking is not possible,” said Miguel Nicolelis, a neuroscientist at Duke University.

Heading: Europe, Russia embark on search for life on Mars
Summary: Europe and Russia are set to launch an unmanned spacecraft on Monday to smell Mars’ atmosphere for gassy evidence that life once existed on the Red Planet, or may do so still.

Heading: Dust particles on Earth may have come from stellar explosions
Summary: The team from Michigan State University (MSU) is investigating whether the particles may have formed in a classical nova — a thermonuclear explosion on the surface of a small star which is part of a binary star system – two stars orbiting each other.

Heading: NASA reschedules launch of troubled Mars lander to 2018
Summary: US space agency NASA said on Wednesday that its Mars lander is now targeting a new launch window that begins May 5, 2018, with a Mars landing scheduled for November 26, 2018. “We’re excited to be back on the path,” John Grunsfeld, NASA’s associate administrator, said in a statement, Xinhua reported.

Heading: NASA plans to launch balloon flight in New Zealand
Summary: US space agency NASA is planning to set a record for the longest ever flight for a scientific balloon to be launched in New Zealand next month.

Heading: Object located around black hole 5 bn light-years from Earth measured
Summary: A team of scientists has accurately detected a structure in the innermost region of a quasar at a distance of more than five billion light-years from Earth. It’s the most accurate measure achieved until now of such a small and distant object, and it has been achieved thanks to the so-called gravitational microlensing effect, caused by stars belonging to a galaxy between us and the quasar, and which may magnify tiny regions within the quasar.

Heading: Expedition 46 astronauts return to Earth, key Mars research on
Summary: After conducting some key research on the International Space Station (ISS) to send humans to Mars in the near future, astronaut Scott Kelly and cosmonauts Mikhail Kornienko and Sergey Volkov safely returned to Earth on Wednesday.

Heading: Work, view of Himalayan lakes kept Scott Kelly ‘sane’ on ISS
Summary: The view of rainbow-hued Himalayan lakes and steady work helped Scott Kelly stay sane during the 340 days he spent aboard the International Space Station (ISS), the NASA astronaut said days after returning to Earth from the record-setting mission.

Heading: New Horizons spots methane on Pluto’s snowcapped peaks
Summary: The New Horizons team has discovered a chain of exotic snowcapped mountains stretching across the dark expanse on Pluto, informally named “Cthulhu Regio”…

Heading: Gene for greying hair found for the first time
Summary: In a first, an international team of researchers has identified a gene for greying hair, confirming greying has a genetic component and is not just environmental. The study, published in the journal Nature Communications, analysed a population of over 6,000 people with varied ancestry across Latin America to identify new genes associated with hair colour, greying, density and shape.

Heading: Ageing begins even before you are born: Study
Summary: The process of ageing begins even before we are born, researchers say, adding that providing mothers with antioxidants during pregnancy may help their offspring to age more slowly in adulthood.

Heading: 520-million-year-old fossilised nervous system found
Summary: Scientists have found one of the oldest and most detailed fossils of the central nervous system yet identified, from a crustacean-like animal that lived more than 500 million years ago.

Heading: Barack Obama welcomes NASA’s Scott Kelly back to Earth
Summary: US President Barack Obama spoke on phone with NASA astronaut Scott Kelly on Wednesday, welcoming him back to Earth from his yearlong mission on the International Space Station (ISS), the White House said. Obama thanked Kelly “for his participation in important research about what it will take for us to make long journeys in space, and for inspiring a new generation…

Heading: SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launched
Summary: American aerospace manufacturer and space transport services company SpaceX announced that its Falcon 9 rocket was launched into space but as expected failed to land the vehicle on a drone ship at sea afterward.

Heading: NASA gives nod to quieter supersonic passenger jet
Summary: The US space agency has finally given green signal for preliminary design of “low-boom” supersonic passenger plane that will take people places with an unimaginable speed. This is the first in a series of “X-planes” in NASA’s New Aviation Horizons initiative, introduced in the agency’s fiscal year 2017 budget.

Heading: Hubble spots farthest known galaxy in universe
Summary: An international team of astronomers on Thursday said that using the Hubble Space Telescope they have spotted the farthest galaxy ever seen in the universe.

Heading: NASA: Recent drought in Levant region worst in past 900 years
Summary: The recent drought that began in 1998 in the eastern Mediterranean Levant region — comprising Cyprus, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Palestine, Syria, and Turkey — is about 10 to 20 percent drier than the worst drought of the past nine centuries, a NASA study has found.

Heading: Elon Musk’s SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launch canceled at final countdown
Summary: At the last second, Elon Musk’s SpaceX scrubbed plans to launch a Falcon 9 rocket on Sunday, again delaying an attempt to put an satellite into orbit and then land the vehicle’s first stage intact on a sea platform, a step that may eventually slash costs.

Heading: Watch out Superman, Kryptonite comes closer to reality!
Summary: Kryptonite may no longer be just the stuff of fiction feared by caped superheroes as a team of scientists has got the formula! Theoretical chemists from the Institute of Physical Chemistry of the Polish Academy of Sciences have found how to synthesize the first binary compound of krypton and oxygen: a krypton oxide.

Heading: Milky Way’s cold clouds shine in new in-depth cosmic map
Summary: Showing off the Milky Way clouds like never before, a new cosmic map covers our galaxy’s densest regions of star formation. APEX, the Atacama Pathfinder EXperiment telescope, is located at 5100 metres above sea level on the Chajnantor Plateau in Chile’s Atacama region…

Heading: Climate change could kill 500,000 ‘extra’ by 2050
Summary: A new study has revealed that climate change could cause significant changes to global diets, leading to more than half a million extra deaths by 2050. The research is the strongest evidence yet that climate change could have damaging consequences for food production and health worldwide…

Heading: Clues to life on Mars may be found on ‘driest place on Earth’
Summary: NASA scientists are exploring the “driest place on Earth” that provides a Mars-like environment to study the limits of life, and test drilling and life-detection technologies that may be sent to the red planet in the future.

Heading: Feeding babies peanuts cuts allergy risk
Summary: Science still might not know as to why some people are allergic to things and others aren’t, but a team of researchers has found out a way to ward off peanut allergies.

Heading: Hubble team reaches Big Bang, shatters cosmic distance record
Summary: By pushing NASAs Hubble Space Telescope to its limits, an international team of astronomers has shattered the cosmic distance record by measuring the farthest galaxy ever seen in the universe.

Heading: US astronaut Scott Kelly heads home after nearly a year in space
Summary: After nearly a year orbiting the Earth, US astronaut Scott Kelly was on the cusp of coming home after spending more time in space than any other American.

Heading: NASA denies Indian teen’s claim on internship
Summary: US National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) has denied an Indian teen girl’s claim that she was selected for its prestigious Goddard Internship Program…

Heading: New NASA images may solve mystery of Mars moon Phobos
Summary: NASA scientists are closer to solving the mystery of how Phobos was formed, by using the spectral images of the Mars’ moon captured in ultraviolet by the MAVEN mission.

Heading: Parrots may be as smart as apes: Study
Summary: The mental skills of some birds such as parrots may match those of apes, including their capability of thinking logically, of recognising themselves in the mirror and of empathy, a new study has claimed.

Heading: Total solar eclipse on March 9
Summary: A total eclipse of the Sun will occur on March 9. From India, it will be seen as partial solar eclipse at sunrise. The same will be visible from most places of India except from North West and western parts of the country. In most places of India, the partial phase of the eclipse begins before sunrise i.e. partially eclipsed sunrise will take place.

Heading: Why no alien has listened to us till date
Summary: Why have we not received any call from the aliens out there yet? What if extraterrestrial observers called but nobody on Earth heard? As scientists step up their search for other life in the universe, two astrophysicists from McMaster University are proposing a way to make sure we don’t miss the signal if extraterrestrial observers try to contact us first.

Heading: Ozone pollution may not lead to decline of natural ecosystems
Summary: Surface ozone, an abundant chemical known to be toxic to many species of vegetation and to humans, does not necessarily inhibit the productivity of natural ecosystems, says a new study.

Heading: NASA’s Chandra observatory spots oldest light in the universe
Summary: Using the data from NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory, astronomers have discovered a jet from a very distant supermassive black hole being illuminated by the oldest light in the universe.

Heading: NASA sees record number of astronaut applications
Summary: NASA has received a record 18,300 resumes from people keen on becoming astronauts, the US space agency has said.

Heading: Location of ‘fast radio burst’ found in distant universe
Summary: In a first, a team of scientists has tracked down the location of a fast radio burst (FRB), confirming that these short but spectacular flashes of radio waves originate in the distant universe. The breakthrough was made using the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) radio telescopes in eastern Australia and the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan’s Subaru telescope in Hawaii.

Heading: How ageing rewires our brain
Summary: Pointing to a potentially new direction for age-related cognitive care, scientists have found more evidence that ageing brains work differently than younger brains when performing the same memory task.

Heading: Star system with longest-lasting stellar eclipse discovered
Summary: Scientists have discovered a new star system where every 69 years the bigger star disappears in a near-total eclipse that lasts for three and a half years, setting a record for the longest duration stellar eclipse and the longest period between eclipses in a binary system.

Heading: China to launch second orbiting space lab Tiangong-2, Shenzhou-11 spacecraft
Summary: China will send its second orbiting space lab Tiangong-2 into space in the third quarter of this year, which is expected to dock with a cargo ship next year, authorities said on Sunday. As part of the country’s space lab programme, China also plans to launch the Shenzhou-11 spacecraft, which will carry two astronauts on board, in the fourth quarter of this year to dock with Tiangong-2, Xinhua news agency reported.

Heading: 5D data storage could record human history forever
Summary: Opening a new era of eternal data archiving, scientists at University of Southampton have developed the recording and retrieval processes of five dimensional (5D) digital data using ultrafast laser writing in nanostructured glass.

Heading: Astronomers record rotation of cloudy ‘super-Jupiter’
Summary: In a maiden attempt to decode the rotation of a massive exoplanet, astronomers using Hubble Space Telescope have measured the rotation rate of a cloudy “super-Jupiter” by observing the varied brightness in its atmosphere.

Heading: Nasa spaceman Scott Kelly sees International Space Station mission as ‘steppingstone’ to Mars
Summary: NASA’s first and only yearlong spaceman Scott Kelly will go through a series of physical and medical tests as soon as he returns from the International Space Station (ISS) in a few days.

Heading: Death by meteorite?
Summary: The fall of meteorites and the passing of comets often become objects of fascination in the scientific as well as religious communities across the world.

Heading: Rare supernova ‘impostor’ found in nearby galaxy
Summary: A team of astronomers has found a rare supernova “impostor” in a nearby galaxy.

Heading: Fossil analysis pushes back common ancestors of apes and humans link by 2 mn years
Summary: The common ancestors of apes and humans, Chororapithecus abyssinicus, evolved in Africa not Eurasia, two million years earlier than previously thought, says a new study.

Heading: Research finds oxygen was present in Earth’s atmosphere much earlier than assumed
Summary: A geological study based on data from Western Greenland has indicated that small levels of atmospheric oxygen were developed on Earth 3.8 billion years ago, some 0.7-0.8 billion years earlier than thought.

Heading: New NASA telescope, 100 times bigger than Hubble Space Telescope, to unravel dark energy, alien life
Summary: In a fresh attempt to unlock the secrets of the universe, NASA has announced to build a new, wider telescope that will have a view 100 times bigger than that of Hubble Space Telescope.

Heading: Birds of a new feather
Summary: Here’s looking at some of the new avian species discovered in the recent past

Heading: Milky Way’s cold clouds shine in new in-depth cosmic map
Summary: APEX, the Atacama Pathfinder EXperiment telescope, is located at 5100 metres above sea level on the Chajnantor Plateau in Chile’s Atacama region.

Heading: NASA Interstellar Boundary Explorer (IBEX) decodes interstellar magnetic field
Summary: What is out there at the edge of our solar system? Scientists using data from NASA’s Interstellar Boundary Explorer (IBEX) have pinned down an interstellar magnetic field which lies at the very edge of the giant magnetic bubble surrounding our solar system called the heliosphere. Immediately after its 2008 launch, IBEX spotted a curiosity in a thin slice of space: More particles streamed in through a long, skinny swath in the sky than anywhere else.

Heading: US researchers find new way to make nanowire laser
Summary: US researchers have found a new way to produce nanoscale wires, with diametres as small as 200 nanometres, or billionths of a metre, that can serve as tiny, tunable lasers.

Heading: Total solar eclipse coming to Southeast Asia on March 8
Summary: Ever witnessed a total solar eclipse? Here’s a chance for all those space lovers. Come March 8, 2016, the moon will cast its shadow as it is all set to pass in front of the sun, says NASA.

Heading: New technique may help divert Earth-bound asteroids
Summary: Asteroids headed for Earth, if found early enough, can be acted upon to prevent the impact, researchers said.

Heading: Sea level rising faster than ever: Report
Summary: Sea levels rose faster in the past century than during the previous 27 centuries due to man-made global warming, a group of scientists has said in an alarming report.

Heading: Unusual fossil tracks not of swimming dinosaurs: Study
Summary: The unusual 120-million-year-old fossillised footprint tracks found in China may have been left behind by massive four-legged sauropod dinosaurs that walked on land, and not by swimming animals, scientists suggest.

Heading: So, how long does it take cloudy ‘super-Jupiter’ to rotate once?
Summary: In a first, a team of astronomers using NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope has measured the rotation rate of an extreme exoplanet by observing the varied brightness in its atmosphere.

Heading: Chinese baby born after surviving as frozen embryo for 12 years
Summary: A healthy baby has been born in China’s northwest Shaanxi Province from an embryo frozen 12 years ago, the country’s longest preserved test tube baby.

Heading: Time for India to join global space rule framing to avoid NPT like mistake, say experts
Summary: The race for resources in the Moon and Mars has already begun with the outer space already being securitised and if not still weaponised. But Indian government is yet to take lead in the global efforts to frame rules for outer space. Is it the right approach, question space experts and senior scientists.

Heading: Now, 5D black hole may ‘break’ Albert Einstein’s general relativity
Summary: A team of British researchers has successfully simulated a black hole shaped like a very thin ring, which gives rise to a series of ‘bulges’ connected by strings that become thinner over time.

Heading: NASA releases new space tourism posters
Summary: The US space agency NASA is not only full of scientists but it is also home to artistic dreamers and thinkers who once again stormed the internet with the release of new space tourism posters.

Heading: ISRO to launch Cryogenic mk-III based GSLV vehicle in Dec
Summary: The Indian Space Research Organasion (ISRO) has confirmed that it would launch the Cryogenic mark-III based GSLV satellite launch vehicle during December this year.

Heading: Space odyssey to broadcast people’s messages to stars
Summary: Messages from around the world will be beamed into space at the speed of light as part of a cultural project to create a celestial time capsule, scientists say.

Heading: Gravitational waves detected as 2 black holes collided; ‘Whoooop!’
Summary: In momentous news for humanity, it has been reported that Albert Einstein theory’s gravitational waves have been detected 100 years after teh great scientist’s prediction. As soon as the news broke on Thursday, scientists discussing the significance of the major discovery revealed that it would enable us not just to see the stars, but also to listen to them.

Heading: Now, world’s most accurate clock ever
Summary: A team of physicists in Germany has built the most accurate timepiece on Earth, achieving unprecedented levels of accuracy with a new atomic clock.

Heading: Ancient Roman skeletons reveal human migration pattern
Summary: A study of 2,000-year-old skeletons in two Roman cemeteries has revealed that some migrants were likely from outside Roman Empire, possibly from North Africa and the Alps.

Heading: Watch out! Bacteria can see like human beings
Summary: It has taken scientists over 300 years to finally figure out how bacteria “see” their world, and they do it in a remarkably similar way to us.

Heading: North Korea’s new satellite flew over Super Bowl site
Summary: Here’s a bit of Super Bowl trivia: North Korea’s newest satellite passed almost right over the stadium just an hour after it ended.

Heading: Ian Somerhalder, Nikki Reed want to have kids
Summary: “The Vampire Diaries” star Ian Somerhalder has revealed he and wife Nikki Reed are trying for a baby.

Heading: How to have better sex: Play the music loud tonight, says Sonos, Apple Music study
Summary: Here is how to have better sex: Increase the volume of your favourite number and reap the results as the loud sound will ensure your way to better and steamier sex, an interesting study has revealed…

Heading: NASA turns to sports balls to understand aerodynamics
Summary: NASA scientists, including one of Indian-origin, are studying the aerodynamics involved in sports balls moving through the air in order to learn how to make aircraft more Earth-friendly or help a spacecraft take the most efficient route to Mars.

Heading: New fossil fish species living 92 mn years ago with giant mouth discovered
Summary: Researchers have discovered two new fossil fish species that could swing the jaws open extra wide, like a parachute, from the Cretaceous Period, about 92 million years ago, when dinosaurs roamed Earth.

Heading: US climate change ruling raises doubts in India, China: NYT
Summary: The US Supreme Court’s surprise decision to halt President Barack Obama’s climate change regulation could imperil the Paris accord and raise doubts in India and China about US commitments, according to the New York Times.

Heading: Scientists discover hidden galaxies behind Milky Way 250 mn light years away from Earth
Summary: A team of international scientists has discovered hundreds of hidden galaxies hidden from view until now by our own galaxy, the Milky Way, some 250 million light years away from the Earth.

Heading: PM Narendra Modi lauds detection of gravitational waves
Summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday expressed his happiness over historic detection of gravitational waves and lauded the role of Indian scientists in the project.

Heading: Albert Einstein writings show theory 100 years ahead of time
Summary: It took over a century, but the theory from Albert Einstein handwritten neatly on paper that is now yellowing has finally been vindicated.

Heading: Scientists say Albert Einstein’s gravitational waves detected
Summary: Gravitational waves detected: In a landmark discovery for physics and astronomy, scientists said today they have glimpsed the first direct evidence of gravitational waves, ripples in the fabric of space-time that Albert Einstein had predicted a century ago.

Heading: Aliens? Interstellar odyssey to broadcast people’s messages to star
Summary: Have a message to convey to the aliens out there? Write one fast as researchers are set to beam selective messages from around the world into space at the speed of light to create a celestial time capsule.

Heading: Rocky exoplanets have Earth-like interiors: Study
Summary: The interior structure of rocky exoplanets orbiting other stars will have interiors very similar to Earth — a thin outer crust, a thick mantle, and a Mars-sized core, researchers have shown using a computer model.

Heading: Future ESA probe to hunt gravitational wave in space
Summary: While the news of gravitational waves being detected on Earth is hailed as a landmark discovery, scientists will be looking forward to a major European Space Agency (ESA) mission that would seek to detect the elusive phenomenon – in space.

Heading: ‘Gravitational waves detected 100 years after Albert Einstein’s prediction’
Summary: Scientists said on Thursday they have detected the existence of gravitational waves, which were predicted by Albert Einstein’s theory of general relativity 100 years ago.

Heading: Dietary changes may have shaped human evolution: Study
Summary: A possible early human ancestor, Australopithecus sediba, didn’t have the jaw and tooth structure necessary to exist on a steady diet of hard foods, suggesting that dietary changes were shaping the evolutionary paths of early humans, according to a study.

Heading: X-rays and nanoparticles combo can kill cancer: Study
Summary: Nanoparticles used in combination with X-rays are a viable method for killing cancer cells deep within the living body, a new study has found.

Heading: Climate change will make transatlantic flights longer due to high altitude winds: Study
Summary: Flights from Europe to North America will take slightly longer and nudge up airline fuel costs if climate change strengthens high altitude winds as widely expected, a study said on Wednesday.

Heading: Meteorite death: NASA discounts Vellore theory, Indian institute says analysis on
Summary: Meteorite death: Scientists at the US space agency NASA have discounted reports that an Indian bus driver in Tamil Nadu’s Vellore city was killed by a meteorite, but Indian experts said this can only be ruled out after “detailed analysis”.

Heading: Meteorite death in India: Man in Tamil Nadu’s Vellore not killed by meteorite, says NASA
Summary: Meteorite death in India: Scientists at the US space agency NASA have discounted reports that an Indian bus driver in Tamil Nadu was killed by a meteorite, saying he was likely hit by a land based explosion.

Heading: Cotton candy machines pave the way for artificial organs
Summary: Taking a cue from cotton candy machines, scientists have developed a 3D artificial capillary system that can keep living cells viable and functional for more than a week, thus paving the way for making life-sized artificial livers, kidneys, bones and other essential organs.

Heading: Google doodle: ‘Father’ of periodic table on 182nd birth anniversary gets ‘doodled’
Summary: A Google doodle dedicated to Russian chemist Dmitri Mendeleev was unveiled by Internet search giant Google on Monday on his 182nd birth anniversary today.

Heading: Maths comes to rescue of global human health
Summary: Maths is a scary subject for many — but for scientist at Universities of York in the US and Turin in Italy, advanced calculations can help improve human health globally.

Heading: Asteroid ‘TX68’ to pass by Earth on March 5 at 9,000-17,000 km distance: NASA
Summary: An asteroid, named ‘TX68’, is expected to make its closest approach to Earth on March 5 will pass peacefully without disturbing our world at a distance of between 9,000-17,000 km, says NASA.

Heading: Russians on International Space Station go spacewalking to collect experiments, test glue
Summary: Two Russians took a spacewalk Wednesday to install fresh experiments outside the International Space Station (ISS) and gather biological samples stuck outside for years.

Heading: DNA evidence unearths major population shift at last Ice Age-end
Summary: DNA evidence from the ancient bones and teeth of people who lived in Europe near the end of the last Ice Age shows a major shift in the population around 14,500 years ago during a period of severe climatic instability.

Heading: How early humans evolved by sharing technology, culture
Summary: Our early ancestors managed to evolve and journey across the earth by exchanging and improving their technology, researchers say after analysing Blombos Cave in South Africa.

Heading: China’s ‘man-made sun’ sees ground-breaking progress
Summary: A team of Chinese scientists in Hefei, capital city of east Anhui province, has made an unprecedented breakthrough on an energy generation device that will bring it one step closer to transforming energy into stable, sustainable and controllable resources.

Heading: US space agency NASA’s deep space rocket to launch small satellites, Orion spacecraft
Summary: The US space agency NASA on Tuesday said its new rocket for deep space mission, the Space Launch System (SLS), will carry 13 small satellites along with an uncrewed Orion spacecraft during its first flight in 2018.

Heading: North Korea rocket launch a ‘direct violation’ of UN resolutions: NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg
Summary: NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg today blasted North Korea’s launch of a long-range rocket as a blatant breach of five UN resolutions and demanded Pyongyang comply with international law.

Heading: Scientists investigate suspected meteorite death in southern India
Summary: Indian scientists are investigating whether a man was killed by a meteorite, which if confirmed would be the first recorded death from falling fragments of space rock in almost 200 years.

Heading: NASA spacecraft spots ‘floating’ hills on Pluto
Summary: NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft has captured images of frozen nitrogen glaciers on Pluto carrying numerous ‘floating’ hills that may be fragments of water ice, giving an insight into the dwarf planet’s fascinating and abundant geological activity.

Heading: Prehistoric humans savoured roasted turtles!
Summary: Turtles, or tortoises, are rarely consumed today but a select few cultures, primarily those in East Asia, still consider turtle soup made from the flesh of the turtle a delicacy. And new research has revealed that early humans some 400,000 years ago also savoured roasted turtle delicacies.

Heading: What’s the science behind water skipping spheres
Summary: In your childhood days, you must have tried sending a disk-shaped stone to skip across the surface of the water multiple times. Researchers now reveal why is it so easy to get such impressive water-skipping performance from an elastic ball with only a mediocre launch.

Heading: CO2 from thin air converted directly into clean-burning fuel
Summary: In a first, researchers including one of Indian origin have directly converted carbon dioxide from thin air into methanol fuel – a discovery that can create a sustainable fuel source from greenhouse gas emissions in the near future.

Heading: NASA engineers use Super Bowl to decode aerodynamics
Summary: Aerodynamics engineers including an Indian-origin scientist are studying sports balls to learn lessons in aerodynamics that will help build aircraft more earth-friendly and allow spacecrafts to take the most efficient route to Mars in the future.

Heading: NASA’s New Horizon probe captures Pluto’s mysterious, floating hills
Summary: In yet another example of Pluto’s fascinating and abundant geological activity, NASA’s New Horizon has captured nitrogen ice glaciers carrying an intriguing cargo – numerous, isolated hills that may be fragments of water ice from Pluto’s surrounding uplands.

Heading: New material lights up when spotting explosives
Summary: Scientists have created a new material which lights up if there are molecules from explosives in the vicinity.

Heading: New process to create clean fuel from thin air!
Summary: For the first time, scientists, including one of Indian-origin, have directly converted carbon dioxide from the air into methanol at lower temperatures, an advance that may help create a sustainable fuel source from greenhouse gases.

Heading: China to launch about 40 Beidou satellites by 2020
Summary: China plans to launch some 40 Beidou navigation satellites by 2020 to support its global navigation and positioning network, the media reported on Friday.

Heading: New glowing creatures discovered in Red Sea
Summary: Scientists have discovered a new species of luminous creatures in the Red Sea, living in colonies as garlands of ‘fluorescent lanterns’ and emitting a green glow.

Heading: Battery technology could provide fresh water from salty seas
Summary: The technology that charges batteries for electronic devices could help provide fresh water from salty seas, new research has found.

Heading: Apollo 14 Astronaut Edgar Mitchell, who walked on the Moon, dies at 85: NASA
Summary: Astronaut Edgar Mitchell, a module pilot on Apollo 14 mission that touched down the lunar surface on February 5, 1971, died in Florida this week on the eve of the 45th anniversary of his lunar landing, a NASA statement revealed.

Heading: Scientists find unexpectedly cold grains in ‘Flying Saucer’
Summary: An international team has found unexpectedly cold dust grains in a planet-forming disc nicknamed the “Flying Saucer”, about 400 light-years from Earth.

Heading: DNA data uncovers unknown chapter of human history
Summary: Scientists have uncovered an unknown chapter of human history – a major population turnover in Europe at the end of the last Ice Age about 14,500 years ago, during a period of severe climatic instability.

Heading: China names asteroid after Nobel laureate Tu Youyou
Summary: Chinese authorities have named an asteroid after scientist Tu Youyou who won the 2015 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine for her work with artemisinin, which is now widely used to fight malaria.

Heading: Revealed: Who is having more sex in Britain
Summary: People living in the northeast of England are enjoying more action between the sheet – five times a month at least – than anywhere in Britain, says a new survey.

Heading: NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory spots spectacular jet in faraway galaxy
